tuple.atom: Type of device which started to be used in urban Canada at the time, to alert firefighters in a fire department, of the presence of a fire in the neighbourhood where the alarm box was situated. Must have come from one of Canada's major cities.
To rapidly transmit an alarm of fire to a firefighting force.

Replaced the use of bells and the human voice (shouting) to alert firemen about the existence of fires all while divulging their location.
The first practical fire alarm system was developed in Boston in 1852, by Dr. William Channing and Moses Farmer. It worked on the principal of telegraphy: a signal was sent long distances over wires, by electric transmission. "In the first boxes, a notched code wheel was turned by a crank handle in the front of the box. Then, it evolved with a spring-driven, clockwork-type mechanism which drove the code wheel when activated by a lever." Boxes were put on a pedestal or telephone pole at a street corner. Early boxes were locked with keys which were given to the citizens and policemen who had the responsibility of pulling the lever in the event of a fire. In 1875 a model was made that did not need a key. In 1922, the quick-action door was put on the market.
There are two main components that make up this kind of fire alarm system: the telegraph mechanism, located on a street corner, and the alarm apparatus (gongs and indicators), located inside a fire department's Headquarters. One-way communication between the telegraph and alarm system was made possible by linking both boxes with aerial and/or ground-level wires. Central station equipment would receive the signal, revealing the location of the fire, and would proceed to notify the firehouse nearest to the fire by transmitting another signal to their alarm box.
Red, gable roof type/ Screws in 3 corners of pediment support pipes at top and bottom. Top one is threaded inside.

The box is emptied of its inner box with the mechanism. The inner case could probably well be 1971.0446. (same provenance, technology of the period) The key is present. The mechanism most probably consisted of a bell magnet, signalling key, two line switches, a lightning arrester, a shunt switch.
The first practical fire alarm system was developed in 1852 in Boston, by Dr. William Channing and Moses Farmer. John Nelson Gamewell bought total rights of their invention in 1859. The patents were seized by the U.S. Government after the Civil War and were auctioned. The new owner formed a partnership with Gamewell to become Kennard and Company. In 1879, the Gamewell Fire Alarm Telegraph Company was formed with John N. Nelson as the proprietor. The trademark of the fist holding lightning bolts was registered. By 1910, Gamewell was holding 95% of the market share in USA and was also important in Canada. Gamewell dominated the market.
The Northern Electric Company Ltd. began in 1914 and at some point in her history, began producing Gamewell fire alarm systems.
1) James G. Piatti et S. Frost Piatti, Firefighting Antiques & Memorabilia.
2) Andrew G. Gurka, Hot Stuff ! Firefighting Collectibles, 1994.

SYSTEM WAS DEVELOPED AND PATENTED BY GUARD-X OF MONTREAL. GUARD-X WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1942. IT MANUFACTURED & SOLD THE CARBONTETRACHOLORIDE GRENADE SYSTEM OF FIRE EXTINGUISHERS FOR MAINLY INDUSTRIAL USE IN EASTERN CANADA UNTIL THE SYSTEM WAS DECLARED DANGEROUS AND BANNED IN CANADA IN THE 1950S.

USED, WHEN AFFIXED TO A WALL OR CEILING, TO HOLD A GLASS GRENADE FILLED WITH CHEMICALS FOR FIRE EXTINGUISHING, AND TO BREAK THE GLASS WHEN HEAT FROM A FIRE CAUSES A FUSIBLE LINK TO MELT. ALSO A CARTRIDGE DISCHARGES TO GIVE AN ALARM WHEN THE HAMMER BREAKS THE GLASS.

THE GUARD-X SYSTEM OFFERED THE GREAT ADVANTAGE OF BEING 'AUTOMATIC'. THE MOUNTING HAS A FUSIBLE METAL LINK THAT MELTS AT A 'PRESET' TEMP RELEASING A HAMMER ATTACHED TO A SPRING TO SMASH A GLASS GRENADE WHICH RELEASES CHEMICALS TO SUPPRESS A FIRE WITHIN 800 CU FT. OF THE EXTINGUISHER. IT ALSO COULD BE WIRED TO A BELL.
THIS SET USED IN ONE HOUSE IN OTTAWA (71 ORIN ST.) FROM THE 1940S UP TO 1996 WHEN IT WAS REMOVED
THIS SET USED IN OTTAWA BUT WOULD HAVE BEEN AVAILABLE FOR USE THROUGHOUT EASTERN CANADA

TYPE OF AERIAL LADDER VEHICLE USED IN CANADA. REAR-MOUNTED TYPE OF AERIAL TRUCK BECAME MORE IMPORTANT IN CANADA STARTING IN 1950S BECAUSE IT OFFERED MORE FLEXIBILITY IN NARROW STREETS OF CITIES, THIS MODEL WAS LESS POPULAR IN CANADA THAN U.S.; LESS THAN 30 MODEL B TRUCKS WERE DELIVERED IN CANADA & ONLY 4 WERE AERIAL VERSIONS, ALL REAR-MOUNT TYPE.

MACK MODEL B FIRE TRUCK WAS INTRODUCED IN FALL OF 1954 & MADE UNTIL 1966 OR 1967. MACK CO. WAS FOUNDED IN 1900 & PRODUCED ITS FIRST FIRE TRUCK IN 1911.REAR-MOUNTED TYPE OF AERIAL IS EUROPEAN STYLE, OFFERING GREATER FLEXIBILITY IN NARROW STREETS. THIS MODEL B HAS MAGIRUS AERIAL MADE IN GERMANY, 100 FEET IN LENGTH.

SOMETIMES KNOWN AS A JUMPER OR TWO-WHEELER. FOUR WHEEL TYPES WERE COMMON IN THE USA BUT NOT IN CANADA. REELS WERE USUALLY PULLED BY HAND THOUGH IN EARLIER DAYS OFTEN TOWED BY THE HAND ENGINE. SOMETIMES THEY WERE ELABORATLY DECORATED AND CARIIED LAMPS AND BELLS. THEY ORIGINALLY CARRIED RIVETTED LEATHER HOSE, THEN RUBBER, AFTER ABOUT 1860 AND AROUND 1880 CHANGED TO COTTON RUBBER LINED

Stable Comments: an unknown quantity of oil remains inside oil pan :: Deterioration Notes: engine is supported on a steel pipe frame and mounted on a cast iron base, secured to a hardwood frame - hardwood frame appears structurally secure and sound - localized iron corrosion products around base of engines cast support frame - all engine parts are covered with oily grime deposits and contaminated dirt - majority of rubber coated waterproof hoses are brittle and cracked from ageing and handling - cloth covered wires are also frayed with brittle rubber coating cracking and flaking away - enamel paint finish is abraded and lifting in numerous areas on engine block, base and support frame - a 16' rubber hose with brass connectors appears in good condition but laying directly on concrete floor - rubber remains supple and brass connectors are sound with no visible signs of corrosion - fastening connectors for hose are presumably missing

THIS PROTOTYPE VEHICLE PLAYED A KEY ROLE IN DEVELOPMENT OF A NATIONAL FIRE DEFENCE PLAN FOR CANADA DURING THE 1950S. IT WAS DESIGNED BY ROOTES AUTO. MFG. TO SPECIFICATIONS PROVIDED BY CDN CIVIL DEFENCE AUTHORITIES, AND WAS USED TO TRAIN AUXILLIARY FIRE FIGHTERS. TENDERS FOR FURTHER 50 VEHICLES AWARDED TO CDN MFRS. (REF.2)
TO PUMP WATER TO BE DIRECTED, VIA HOSES, ONTO FIRE IN ORDER TO SUPPRESS/EXTINGUISH IT.

PUMPER HAS 350 GAL. TANK AND 500 GAL. PER MINUTE PUMP. OUTSTANDING FEATURE IS 6-MAN CAB, REQUIRED DURING CANADIAN WINTERS TO ALLOW A FULL CREW TO PROCEED TO A FIRE WITHTHE EQUIPMENT.LESS THE HOSE & LADDERS, IT COST APPROX. $7,000.00.

Came with extra nozzle, model 100, mfr'd by Kiddie./ Model: Cylinder: Quick Aid Snofog/ Serial no.: possible SN./ The cylinder contained Co2 under pressure (emptied by storesman upon receipt). When the valve is opened, the liquid gas emerges as solid pellets or foam which smothers the fire. Has been superseded in modern installations by halogen gas which leaves no residue.

USED AS A SIGNAL TO WARN PEOPLE THAT THERE IS AN UNWANTED FIRE BURNING

THIS BELL WAS PART OF AN "AUTOMATIC" FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM. IT WAS WIRED TO AN ELECTRICAL BOX WHICH WAS CONNECTED TO 11EXTINGUISHER MOUNTINGS. THESE HAD FUSIBLE LINKS WHICH MELTED WHEN A PRESET TEMPERATURE WAS EXCEEDED. WHEN THIS HAPPENED A CONNECTION WAS MADE BY WHICH A SWITCH OPENED SENDING A CURRENT TO THE BELL.
THIS BELL WAS MOUNTED IN THE BASEMENT OF A HOUSE IN OTTAWA (71 ORIN ST.) FROM THE 1940S TO 1966
THIS BELL WAS USED IN OTTAWA BUT WOULD HAVE BEEN AVAILABLE THROUGHOUT N. AMERICA

Manufactured in Canada and also, used by fire departments in Canada.
The Waterous Engine Works Co. started in Canada in 1877 when Charles Waterous bought out the PC Van Brocklin Foundry and changed its name. The firm produced power plant equipment, sawmill equipment, road-making equipment, and steel plates. A subsidiary plant was founded in St. Paul, Minnesota.
Fire hose attachment used to direct a stream of water onto a fire.

The first hand pump patented by Newsham in 1725 had a gooseneck nozzle mounted on top. Eventually, nozzles evolved from stationary mount to being attached to the end of fire hoses. John R. Freeman is credited as being the one who found the best design of a nozzle, in 1888, that would produce the best water stream. Early playpipes were made of leather. This one seems to be early as the handle is made of leather and not metal.
Good, has been soldered near straps ring.
1) Andrew G. Gurka, Hot Stuff! Firefighting Collectibles, 1994.
2) René Talbot, General Catalogue/Catalogue general, ca. 1906.
3) The Waterous Engine Works Co., Fire, Its Newest and Most Successful Conqueror, 1889.
4) The Waterous Engine Works Co., Catalogue, 1906.
5) Web site: www.brantford.library.on.ca, The Brantford Expositor Anniversary Number, 1927, "Waterous.Limited Grew with Brantford", p. 28
Brass nozzle for fire fighters hose with leather straps at screw end on turnable ring/ On screwable front portion inside is a cross symbolled structure for bracing.
Type of device made and used in Canada to alert firefighters in a fire department, of the presence of a fire in the neighbourhood where the alarm box is situated.
To rapidly transmit an alarm of fire to a firefighting force.

This is the inner case of an alarm box. Could very well be part of 1971.0445. Inside is the clockwork operating mechanism. Pulling the lever raised a weight allowing its gravity drop to motivate the clockwork mechanism. This was the preferred technology in northern climates over the spring technology.
The first practical fire alarm system was developed in Boston in1852, by Dr. William Channing and Moses Farmer. It worked on the principal of telegraphy: a signal was sent long distances over wires, by electric transmission. "In the first boxes, a notched code wheel was turned by a crank handle in the front of the box. Then, it evolved with a spring-driven, clockwork-type mechanism which drove the code wheel when activated by a lever." Boxes were put on a pedestal or telephone pole at a street corner. Early boxes were locked with keys which were given to the citizens and policemen who had the responsibility of pulling the lever in the event of a fire. In 1875 a model was made that did not need a key. In 1922, the quick-action door was put on the market.
There are two main components that make up this kind of fire alarm system: the telegraph mechanism, located on a street corner, and the alarm apparatus (gongs and indicators), located inside a fire department's Headquarters. One-way communication between the telegraph and alarm system was made possible by linking both boxes with aerial and/or ground-level wires. Central station equipment would receive the signal, revealing the location of the fire, and would proceed to notify the firehouse nearest to the fire by transmitting another signal to their alarm box.

Box painted red on all sides and black inside/ Air slot in door with brass finger lever/ Inside are clockworks, telegraph sounder and relay with black cast weight/ Relay coils in green/ Telegraph sounder on wood base/ Brass trigger configuration on inside door shaped.

The first practical fire alarm system was developed in 1852 in Boston, by Dr. William Channing and Moses Farmer. John Nelson Gamewell bought total rights of their invention in 1859. The patents were seized by the U.S. Government after the Civil War and were auctioned. The new owner formed a partnership with Gamewell to become Kennard and Company. In 1879, the Gamewell Fire Alarm Telegraph Company was formed with John N. Nelson as the proprietor. The trademark of the fist holding lightning bolts was registered. By 1910, Gamewell was holding 95% of the market share in USA and was also important in Canada. Gamewell dominated the market.
The Northern Electric Company Ltd. began in 1914 and at some point in her history, began producing Gamewell fire alarm systems.
1) James G. Piatti et S. Frost Piatti, Firefighting Antiques & Memorabilia.
2) Andrew G. Gurka, Hot Stuff ! Firefighting Collectibles, 1994.
Cast iron box/ Brass lever/ wood base/ Brass trigger configuration.
Nozzle made in Canada and also used by Canadian firefighters.
Fire hose attachment used to direct a stream of water onto a fire.

The first hand pump patented by Newsham in 1725 had a gooseneck nozzle mounted on top. Eventually, nozzles evolved from stationary mount to being attached to the end of fire hoses. John R. Freeman is credited as being the one who found the best design of a nozzle, in 1888, that would produce the best water stream. After this, many designs appeared on the market.
This one has a controlling (shut-off) nozzle which allows the firefighter to have full control of the stream. This would have been invented by Callahan in 1895, U.S. patent 0541716.

Hose end has threaded union/ Working end has a brass adjustable topper to reduce spray stream/ Around the middle is a harness of leather with 2 'U'-shaped handles/ There is a brass half ring attached behind the nozzle opening/ Fair, leather is cracked, nozzle is dented.

The firm started in Toronto in 1853 as Booth & Sons, Coppersmiths. They were manufacturing all kinds of objects made of copper and brass including utensils, brewery kettles, wash boilers, etc. Then it became known as Booth & Son by 1860. In 1909, the firm now known as Booth Cooper Company Ltd. amalgamated with the firm William Coulter & Sons to form the Booth Coulter Copper & Brass Co. Ltd. In 1923 or 1928, the Coulter family bought out the Booth family and the firm became Coulter Copper & Brass Co. Ltd.

ONEOF THREE HAND PUMPS MADE FOR CITY OF MONTREAL FIRE DEPT. BY W.C. HUNNEMANN & CO. (1838- 1883). TWENTY- THREE HUNNEMANN PUMPERS WERE MADE FOR USE IN CANADA, THE MAJORITY OF THESE FOR USE IN ONTARIO.

WHEN DELIVERED IN 1845, IT WAS EQUIPPED WITH TWO PIPES WITH A STRAIGHT & A BLUNDERBUSS NOZZLE, AND WAS FITTED WITH A HUNNEMAN COUPLING. OF END-STROKE STYLE, THE PUMP HANDLES WERE SWUNG HORIZONTAL ACROSS THE FRONT & REAR OF THE ENGINE & PUMPED UP & DOWN TO FORCE WATER TO FIRE. [REF.2].
THIS PUMP USED BY CITY OF MONTREAL, PQ.
POSSIBLY SOME OR ALL OF THE ORIGINAL WHEELS./ PUMP HANDLES OR "BRAKES" MISSING.

THIS FIRE ENGINE DELIVERED TO CITY OF MONTREAL MUNICIPAL FIRE DEPT. NOV. 1, 1843. THE FIRST OF 3 HUNNEMAN HAND PUMPERS ORDERED WAS DELIVERED SEPT. 7, 1838 ( NO. 182); THE LAST NOV. 1, 1845 (NO. 281). HUNNEMAN CO. EST. 1792; IT BECAME WILLIAM C. HUNNEMAN & CO. IN 1838 TO INCORPORATE OFFICIALLY THE PARTNERSHIP OF THE FATHER AND HIS TWO SONS. WILLIAM C. HUNNEMAN BOUGHT THE PATENT FROM JACOB PERKINS IN 1802.

Type of forcible entry tool used by Canadian firefighters in the course of their duty, when doors are locked.
To forcibly break down a locked or blocked door.

According to an old illustration, this type of firefighting tool was first patented on 23 October,1880 (see Collection Rationalization document in S.I.). The lever system design delivered tremendous force. Was replaced by hydraulic tools and pry bar.

Could also have been part of the Reo ladder truck, 1970.0401, donated to Port Hope Museum.
As a result of the Collection Rationalization Project, this door opener was separated from 1970.0402, to be given a new number of its' own. (SC - Apr. 2008)

Type of fire hose used in Canada to extinguish fires.
Conduct used to circulate water flow from water pond or reservoir.

The first fire hoses were made of leather but the seams were only sewn and not riveted together. Leaks happened frequently. In 1807, James Sellers and Abraham Penock from the Philadelphia Hose Company had the idea of riveting the leather sections together. Riveted leather fire hoses were used until about the third quarter of the 19th century. They tended to be heavy, to rot and to crack .The rubber lined hose was patented in 1821 with James Boyd but it was first used only in 1871 in the United States. Modern fire hoses use a variety of natural and synthetic fabrics and elastomers in their construction. Different types of fire hoses exist: attack hoses, supply hoses, relay hoses, forestry hoses and booster hoses.
* Source: Via Mr. G.W. Shorter, National Research Council.
Hose is black leather; jointed to form a hose by rivets (brass); piece of pipe in hose for preserving purposes.

Type of device made and used in Canada to alert firefighters in a fire department, of the presence of a fire in the neighbourhood where the alarm box is situated. It was used in Ottawa City until 1970 when the City decided to discontinue the use of all alarm box systems. Telephone communication systems replaced the alarm box, in most Canadian cities.
To rapidly transmit an alarm of fire to a firefighting force.

The first practical fire alarm system was developed in Boston in1852, by Dr. William Channing and Moses Farmer. It worked on the principal of telegraphy: a signal was sent long distances over wires, by electric transmission. "In the first boxes, a notched code wheel was turned by a crank handle in the front of the box. Then, it evolved with a spring-driven, clockwork-type mechanism which drove the code wheel when activated by a lever." Boxes were put on a pedestal or telephone pole at a street corner. Early boxes were locked with keys which were given to the citizens and policemen who had the responsibility of pulling the lever in the event of a fire. In 1875 a model was made that did not need a key. In 1922, the quick-action door was put on the market. This model has a quick-action door and an emergency telephone.
There are two main components that make up this kind of fire alarm system: the telegraph mechanism, located on a street corner, and the alarm apparatus (gongs and indicators), located inside a fire department's Headquarters. One-way communication between the telegraph and alarm system was made possible by linking both boxes with aerial and/or ground-level wires. Central station equipment would receive the signal, revealing the location of the fire, and would proceed to notify the firehouse nearest to the fire by transmitting another signal to their alarm box.
Red, modified gable type with yellow door on telephone cabinet/ Painted red.

Typical rectangular shaped box with pediment & roof. Often mounted on telephone poles./ Used by Public Progs. for guided tours (J. Cutting)/ Key: 1-001/ * Source: via Mr. R.J. Gorman, Secretary, Board of Control.
The first practical fire alarm system was developed in 1852 in Boston, by Dr. William Channing and Moses Farmer. John Nelson Gamewell bought total rights of their invention in 1859. The patents were seized by the U.S. Government after the Civil War and were auctioned. The new owner formed a partnership with Gamewell to become Kennard and Company. In 1879, the Gamewell Fire Alarm Telegraph Company was formed with John N. Nelson as the proprietor. The trademark of the fist holding lightning bolts was registered. By 1910, Gamewell was holding 95% of the market share in USA and was also important in Canada. Gamewell dominated the market.
The Northern Electric Company Ltd. began in 1914 and at some point in her history, began producing Gamewell fire alarm systems.
1) David R. Fitzsimons et J. Bernard Matheson, History or the Ottawa Fire Department. 150 Years of Firefighting 1838-1988, 1989, p. 222.
2) James G. Piatti et S. Frost Piatti, Firefighting Antiques & Memorabilia.
3) Andrew G. Gurka, Hot Stuff ! Firefighting Collectibles, 1994.
5) Northern Electric Company Limited, Electrical Supplies, Catalogue no. 5, 1925 (L08543)

The first practical fire alarm system was developed in Boston in1852, by Dr. William Channing and Moses Farmer. It worked on the principal of telegraphy: a signal was sent long distances over wires, by electric transmission. "In the first boxes, a notched code wheel was turned by a crank handle in the front of the box. Then, it evolved with a spring-driven, clockwork-type mechanism which drove the code wheel when activated by a lever." Boxes were put on a pedestal or telephone pole at a street corner. Early boxes were locked with keys which were given to the citizens and policemen who had the responsibility of pulling the lever in the event of a fire. In 1875 a model was made that did not need a key. In 1922, the quick-action door was put on the market. This model has a quick-action door and is made of a die-cast silicon-aluminium alloy called Herculite.
There are two main components that make up this kind of fire alarm system: the telegraph mechanism, located on a street corner, and the alarm apparatus (gongs and indicators), located inside a fire department's Headquarters. One-way communication between the telegraph and alarm system was made possible by linking both boxes with aerial and/or ground-level wires. Central station equipment would receive the signal, revealing the location of the fire, and would proceed to notify the firehouse nearest to the fire by transmitting another signal to their alarm box.
Handle and lever front and lettering 'FIRE" on sides/ Gable roof type/ Hinges on right.

The first practical fire alarm system was developed in 1852 in Boston, by Dr. William Channing and Moses Farmer. John Nelson Gamewell bought total rights of their invention in 1859. In 1879, the Gamewell Fire Alarm Telegraph Company was formed with John N. Nelson as the proprietor. The trademark of the fist holding lightning bolts was registered. Example of type of chemical extinguisher used in Canada. These were very popular in Canadian fire depts., and were used on industrial sites, at airports, railyards, etc. c. 1870S- 1930S. They were still being offered in trade catalogues as late as 1985. (Ref. 1)
Used to suppress or extinguish fire.

Despite coming of other chemicals in extinguishers, soda-acid solution was still available in 1985. The chemical reaction of sodium carbonate dissolved in water and then mixed with acid was discovered in France in 1864, and was soon introduced into North America. Earliest types were hand or horse-drawn on a wagon: c. 1910 these extinguishers became motorized. Popular until c. 1930S, and even later.(Ref. 1)
This type of extinguisher used c.1925 +
This extinguisher was used in Ontario, Canada.

Type of device made and used in Canada to alert fire fighters in a fire department, of the presence of a fire in the neighbourhood where the alarm box is situated.
To rapidly transmit an alarm of fire to a fire fighting force.

The first practical fire alarm system was developed in Boston in1852, by Dr. William Channing and Moses Farmer. It worked on the principal of telegraphy: a signal was sent long distances over wires, by electric transmission. "In the first boxes, a notched code wheel was turned by a crank handle in the front of the box. Then, it evolved with a spring-driven, clockwork-type mechanism which drove the code wheel when activated by a lever." Boxes were put on a pedestal or telephone pole at a street corner. Early boxes were locked with keys which were given to the citizens and policemen who had the responsibility of pulling the lever in the event of a fire. In 1875 a model was made that did not need a key. In 1922, the quick-action door was put on the market.
There are two main components that make up this kind of fire alarm system: the telegraph mechanism, located on a street corner, and the alarm apparatus (gongs and indicators), located inside a fire department's Headquarters. One-way communication between the telegraph and alarm system was made possible by linking both boxes with aerial and/or ground-level wires. Central station equipment would receive the signal, revealing the location of the fire, and would proceed to notify the firehouse nearest to the fire by transmitting another signal to their alarm box.
Key to open interior box door.
Raised relief and lettering on front door and upper pediment.

Typical rectangular shaped box with pediment & roof. Often mounted on telephone poles./ Key: 1-001/ See also 67.0046.
The first practical fire alarm system was developed in 1852 in Boston, by Dr. William Channing and Moses Farmer. John Nelson Gamewell bought total rights of their invention in 1859. The patents were seized by the U.S. Government after the Civil War and were auctioned. The new owner formed a partnership with Gamewell to become Kennard and Company. In 1879, the Gamewell Fire Alarm Telegraph Company was formed with John N. Nelson as the proprietor. The trademark of the fist holding lightning bolts was registered. By 1910, Gamewell was holding 95% of the market share in USA and was also important in Canada. Gamewell dominated the market.
The Northern Electric Company Ltd. began in 1914 and at some point in their history, began producing Gamewell fire alarm systems.
1) James G. Piatti et S. Frost Piatti, Firefighting Antiques & Memorabilia.
2) Andrew G. Gurka, Hot Stuff ! Firefighting Collectibles, 1994.
4) Northern Electric Company Limited, Electrical Supplies, Catalogue no. 5, 1925 (L08543)

Type of device made and used in Canada to alert fire fighters in a fire department, of the presence of a fire in the neighbourhood where the alarm box is situated.

The first practical fire alarm system was developed in Boston in1852, by Dr. William Channing and Moses Farmer. It worked on the principal of telegraphy: a signal was sent long distances over wires, by electric transmission. "In the first boxes, a notched code wheel was turned by a crank handle in the front of the box. Then, it evolved with a spring-driven, clockwork-type mechanism which drove the code wheel when activated by a lever." Boxes were put on a pedestal or telephone pole at a street corner. Early boxes were locked with keys which were given to the citizens and policemen who had the responsibility of pulling the lever in the event of a fire. In 1875 a model was made that did not need a key. In 1922, the quick-action door was put on the market. This model has a quick-action door and is made of a die-cast silicon-aluminium alloy called Herculite.
There are two main components that make up this kind of fire alarm system: the telegraph mechanism, located on a street corner, and the alarm apparatus (gongs and indicators), located inside a fire department's Headquarters. One-way communication between the telegraph and alarm system was made possible by linking both boxes with aerial and/or ground-level wires. Central station equipment would receive the signal, revealing the location of the fire, and would proceed to notify the firehouse nearest to the fire by transmitting another signal to their alarm box.
Keys to open front door lock.
Fire box painted red/ Pull down lever painted white.
Raised decorative reliefs on front door and upper pediment.

Typical rectangular shaped box with pediment & roof. Often mounted on telephone poles./ See also 67.0045.
The first practical fire alarm system was developed in 1852 in Boston, by Dr. William Channing and Moses Farmer. John Nelson Gamewell bought total rights of their invention in 1859. The patents were seized by the U.S. Government after the Civil War and were auctioned. The new owner formed a partnership with Gamewell to become Kennard and Company. In 1879, the Gamewell Fire Alarm Telegraph Company was formed with John N. Nelson as the proprietor. The trademark of the fist holding lightning bolts was registered. By 1910, Gamewell was holding 95% of the market share in USA and was also important in Canada. Gamewell dominated the market.
The Northern Electric Company Ltd. began in 1914 and at some point in their history, began producing Gamewell fire alarm systems.

Type of equipment used on fire trucks in Canadian fire departments. LaFrance seemed to have had a special agreement with Sterling for warning apparatus on their trucks. LaFrance had established a subsidiary firm in Toronto in 1915.
Produce a loud sound to warn of emergency vehicle passing by.
This technology replaced bells and hand-cranked sirens as warning signals for traffic clearance during emergency.

The company was first incorporated as Inter-State Machinetool in 1919. In 1925, the company became The Sterling Siren Fire Alarm Co. Inc.

THIS SYSTEM WAS DEVELOPED & PATENTED BY GUARD-X OF MONTREAL. GUARD-X WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1942. ITMANUFACTURED & SOLD THE CARBONTET GRENADE SYSTEM OF FIRE EXTINGUISHERS FOR MAINLY INDUSTRIAL USE IN EASTERN CANADA UNTIL THE SYSTEM WAS DECLARED DANGEROUS AND BANNED IN CANADA IN THE 1950S
USED TO SMOTHER A FIRE WITH THE CARBONTETRACHLORIDE IT CONTAINS WHEN THE GLASS IS SMASHED WITH A HAMMER ATTACHED TO THE EXTINGUISHER HOLDER.

THE GUARD-X SYSTEM OFFERED THE GREAT ADVANTAGE OF BEING 'AUTOMATIC' AS IT HAD A FUSIBLE METAL LINK THAT MELTED AT A 'PRESET' TEMPERATURE RELEASING A HAMMER ATTACHED TO A SPRING WHICH SMASHED THE GLASS GRENADE RELEASING CHEMICALS TO SUPPRESS A FIRE WITHIN 800 CU FT OF THE EXTINGUISHER. IT ALSO COULD BE WIRED TO A FIRE BELL.
THESE GRENADES WERE USED IN A HOUSE IN OTTAW (71 ORIN ST.) FROM THE 1940S UP TO 1996
USED IN OTTAWA BUT WOULD HAVE BEEN AVAILABLE THROUGHOUT EASTERN CANADA
CARBONTETRACHLORIDE IS DYED RED/ UNCOLOURED GLASS

One of the most popular brands of life nets used by fire departments. Type of fire equipment available on Canadian fire trucks for rescue operations in the absence of aerials or in case other means of escape could not work. It was used only as the last possibility because they were difficult to hold with the weight of the victim accentuated by gravity.
Portable net for attempting to catch victims or firefighters falling or jumping from upper floors of a burning building.

When pressure is applied onto the automatic lock, the net opens instantly. Rope nets were the first kind manufactured then came this canvas type. Browder type of life net seems to have been the main supply of life nets for the Ottawa Fire Department. They were sold by important fire fighting equipment companies such as LaFrance in Toronto, Bickle-Seagrave in Woodstock. Pierre Thibault was selling the Atlas brand, a life net very similar to the Browder type and even called "The Atlas Life Saving Machine ".
Used by the Ottawa Fire Department
Canvas is cream colour with black and red print/ Metal frame is a combination of polished metal and dark green/ Reddish felt over frame/ Leather is brownish red
Life net can be folded and stored in halves or in quarters.

TO DRAW, EXPEL UNDER FORCE & DIRECT A STREAM OF WATER, FOR USE IN EXTINGUISHING A FIRE.

INVENTION OF HAND PUMP DATES TO MID-17TH C. (HAUTSH OF NUREMBURG); BEST KNOWN & MOST SUCCESSFUL IS NEWSHAM FIRE ENGINE, PATENTED 1721 & 1725. NEWHAM & OTHER EUROPEAN MADE PUMPERS WERE IMPORTED INTO N. AMERICA UNTIL C. LAST QUARTER OF 18TH C., WHEN THEY BEGAN TO BE MFD. IN USA. PROMINANT EARLY N. AMERICAN MFGS. INCLUDE RICHARD MASON, JAMES SMITH, WILLIAM HINNEMAN. SENECA FALLS BECAME THE FIRE ENGINE BUILDING CAPITAL OF THE USA BECAUSE OF THE WATER POWER OF THE SENECA RIVER. GLEASON & BAILEY CO. OPERATED THERE 1845-1900, AND WERE PROMINENT BUILDERS OF ALL TYPES OF HORSE AND HAND DRAWN FIRE APPARATUS. IN 1901 THE COMPANY MERGED WITH OTHERS TO FORM THE INTERNATIONAL FIRE ENGINE CO.. IN 1904 INTERNAT'L BECAME AMERICAN LAFRANCE FIRE ENGINE CO., OPERATING UNTIL 1927. (REF.1)

tuple.atom: American-LaFrance Fire Engine Co. of Canada Ltd.

AMERICAN LAFRANCE FIRE VEHICLES WERE VERY POPULARIN CANADA, AND MANY WERE BUILT IN THE CANADIAN PLANT LOCATED IN TORONTO. THIS EXAMPLE WAS THE FIRST MOTORIZED FIRE VEHICLE USED BY THE GLACE BAY, NS FIRE DEPT. IT WAS PURCHASED NEW IN 1918, AND WAS THE ONLY PUMPER IN GLACE BAY UNTIL 1931, WHEN A 2ND TRUCK ACQ'D. (REF. 3).
USED TO TRANSPORT FIRE FIGHTING PERSONNEL & EQ. TO SITE OF FIRE, AND TO PUMP AND DIRECT WATER ONTO FIRE.

TYPE 12 VEHICLE INTRODUCED IN 1911, THE FIRST MODEL TO USE A ROTARY GEAR PUMP. THE STEERING WHEEL IS LOCATED ON THE RIGHT SIDE, AND A CHAIN DROVE THE POWER TO THE REAR WHEELS. A CRANK WAS NEEDED TO START THE MOTOR. IT WAS ORIGINALLY FITTED WITH SOLID RUBBER TIRES: IN 1931 PNEUMATIC TIRES WERE INSTALLED BY GLACE BAY FIRE FIRE DEPT., WHEN THE PUMPER WAS REPAIRED FOLLOWING AN ACCIDENT. IT HAS A 30 GALLON CHEMICAL TANK, 1200 FEET OF 2 1/2 INCH HOSE, A 12-FOOT ROOF LADDER, AND A 24-FOOT EXTENSION LADDER. THE TRUCK WAS LICENCED ALMOST CONTINUOUSLY FROM 1918 TO 1968, AND WAS IN WORKING ORDER WHEN ACQUIRED BY THE MUSEUM IN 1969. (REF. 3)
THIS TRUCK USED IN GLACE BAY, NS.
SAID TO BE COMPLETE & OPERATIONAL IN 1969 WHEN ACQUIRED BY NMST. Restaured at NMST after aquisition

THIS ENGINE WAS USED TO FIGHT THE GREAT OTTAWA-HULL FIRE OF APRIL 1900. LATTERLY IT BELONGED TO NRC BUILDING DIV., & BEFORE THAT TO NCC/ TYPE OF FIRE ENGINE BOUGHT BY CANADIAN CITIES, PARTICULARLY FROM 1860S, EG.SAINT JOHN-2 1863, 1 IN 1864; WINDSOR IN 1868, & MORE AFTER 1870. OTTAWA PURCHASED UNION IN 1870.

BUILDERS WERE THE 1ST TO INTRODUCE THE "CRANE NECK" ENGINE WHICH GREATLY REDUCED THE TURNING CIRCLE OF LARGE FIRE ENGINES, IMPROVING MANOEUVRABILITY. AMOSKEAG STEAM PUMP DESIGN WAS CONCEIVED BY N.S. BEAN, LOCOMOTIVE WORKMAN FROM MANCHESTER LOCOCMOTIVE WORKS. SIZE CORRESPONDS TO PUMPING CAPACITY OF ENGINE. STEAMERS WERE FIRST INVENTED IN 1852 BY ALEXANDER & MOSES LOTTA & ABEL SHANK. GRADUALLY THEY REPLACED HAND PUMPS IN CANADIAN CITIES, & WERE LATER GRADUALLY REPLACED BY MOTORIZED FIRE VEHICLES STARTING CA. 1910. STEAM PUMPERS WERE TYPE OF FIRE ENGINE BOUGHT BY CITIES WHICH HAD ADEQUATE WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS FOR THIS TYPE OF FIRE FIGHTING.
1867 TO AT LEAST 1900, AS ENGINE WAS STILL IN USE AT THAT DATE.

EXAMPLE OF VERY EARLY FIRE ENGINE EMPLOYING METAL VALVES (CHARLES SIMPKIN, C. 1792). HADLEY & SIMPKIN ARRANGED HANDLES ON THEIR ENGINES THAT COULD BE FOLDED UP DURING TRANSPORT (C. 1820), AND FITTED SPRINGS TO THE ENGINE CARRIAGE. THIS MODEL PERMITTED A SECOND CREW TO TREAD PUMP, THEREBY INCREASING THE NORMAL WATER DELIVERY.
THIS PUMPER POSSIBLY USED IN N. HATLEY, PQ.

Hand pulled or horse-drawn/soda-acid chemical solution

R.S. Bickle Co. formed in Winnipeg in 1906, and specialized first in the manufacture of 2-wheeled horse-drawn chemical extinguishers. In 1913, they opened a new factory in Woodstock, Ont. in order to access Eastern market. The company renamed Bickle Fire Engine [Co.] in 1922.
Used to suppress or extinguish fire.

Chemical fire wagons were very popular in Cdn. municipal fire depts., and on industrial sites, in airports, railyards, etc. Despite the coming of other chemicals in extinguishers, soda-acid solution was still available in 1985. The chemical reaction of sodium carbonate dissolved in water and then mixed with acid was discovered in France in 1864, and soon introduced to North America. The earliest were hand or horse-drawn on a wagon: c. 1910 these extinguishers became motorized. Popular until 1930S, and even later. (Ref. 1)
This chemical fire extinguishing device used c. 1906 +
Body consists of along metal cylinder (silver) in which water is compressed. At the front is a metal box containing two bottles of sulphuric acid and a bag of bicarbonate of soda.

This truck was mfr'd. in Toronto, Ont., Canada by a Canadian subsidiary of American LaFrance, LaFrance Fire Engine and Foamite Ltd. (Est. 1925). It was purchased and used by the City of Toronto for 25 years. City of Toronto purchased 14 170-PJC pumpers from 1951-1955. (Ref. 1)
To transport fire fighting personnel and equipment to the scene, and to pump water onto the fire.

700 Series models offered 1945-1957, and continued to influence fire truck design into the 1980s. These trucks had a closed canopy, and then- revolutionary cab-forward design, the motor being located in the back. It is generally believed that more 700 Series trucks were built than any other singular types in the world. (Ref.2)

Long-term storage procedures. Draining of fluids, fogging of engine interior, etc.

Radiator cap was removed. Drain cock on radiator and on water jacket (2, 1 on either side of engine) were opened and coolant allowed to drain. Cooling system was air dried (shop-vac) for 1 hour. Drain cocks were closed. Spark plugs (1/cylinder), dipstick and oil fill cap were removed. Oil drain plug was removed and oil drained. Drain plug reinstalled, 2-3 litres of 30 non-detergent oil was added. Engine fogged. Spark plugs, dipstick and fill cap reinstalled.
Yes - Vehicle may contain radiator antifreeze (ethylene glycol.)
Metals: Steel, iron, chrome/ Rubber/ Leather.

Stable Comments: Artifact appears to be stable. :: Deterioration Notes: Moderate to heavy dust and dirty accretions on most surfaces. Various scratches, abrasions and areas of paint loss (heavy in some locations.) Rust apparent where iron alloys substrate has been exposed. Rear seat (passenger side) is highly worn with loss of surface and interior padding.

Roy Belshaw was a life-long Waterous employee. In 1993, he rescued (with permission) an extraordinary collection of Waterous company material from the dumpster into which it had been thrown. Over and above the historical significance of the Waterous firm, it is the completeness of the records saved by Mr. Belshaw that make this collection unique. For once, a detailed internal study of a Canadian firm like this can be carried out against its record of production. The collection also includes a great deal of material that documents the social and plant life of the workers.
Used to control the flow of water from a fire hose.

The Waterous firm (under various names) was one of Canada's pioneering equipment manufacturers. Located in Brantford, it was one of Canada's longest lasting heavy equipment manufacturers - producing agricultural, steam, fire, and especially logging equipment from 1844-1992.
Heavy brass nozzle with threaded interior and black rubber gasket.
1) Acquisition proposal and Appraisal report in S.I.
2) Pay stubs and International Association of Machinist membership booklets in S.I. for 2009.0273 (belonged to Roy Belshaw)
3) Certified Appraisal Report of Waterous Collection Items", by Gordon R. Hume, 2009.

Clothing & personal safety apparatus;:;Vêtements et équipement de protection individuelle

An example of a modern type of fire helmet worn by Canadian firefighters. Some fire departments still choose the classic leather type of helmet, but made in a modern material like Kevlar or fibreglass composites. Cairns brothers has always been an important provider of fire helmets to Canadian fire departments since the early 1990’s. MSA, the current owner of Cairns, was another. This helmet (no. 2813) belonged to the firefighter Richard Malton of the Ottawa Fire Department. He began in the service in March 1984, In May 2005 he became a lieutenant and the helmet was no longer used. Usually, by regulation all firefighting protective clothing must be changed after five years of service. If the condition is good, The Ottawa Fire Department sends such items to the training centre for a second life. This helmet had been used for only about 6-7 months. It was Mr. Malton’s second or third helmet.
A piece of equipment worn ro protect a firefighter form injury during firefighting.

This type of helmet became available circa 1980 in Canadian fire departments. In Ottawa, it was used since the later 1970’s to meet the new OHSA (Occupational Health and Safety Administration) regulation for firefighters’ helmets. It was probably the 660 Phoenix helmet then. The Metro 660 was introduced in 1981. It was the first helmet produced by Cairns with a fiberglass-reinforced composite shell. It also meets the NFPA (National Fire Protection Association) regulation. The face shield of Polyaralyte was introduced in1983 for this type of helmet but had existed before in other materials. Until about the 1950’s, Canadian firefighters used leather, plastic (polycarbonate) or aluminum helmets. The plastic ones melted despite the manufacturers’ claims and were not stable in elevated areas with wind. The aluminum ones, first introduced by Cairns in the 1920’s, were comfortable but heated up in fires. During WWII their production was discontinued. In 1836 H.T. Gratacap of NewYork designed the first American fire helmet. The Cairns brothers operated a metal badge, button and insignia making company in NYC and came up with the idea of mounting an identification tag to the front of Gratacap’s helmets. The two companies cooperated until Gratacap’s retirement after which the Cairns took over production in 1868. With time, they diversified their production to other firefighting equipment. In 2000 Cairns was bought by Mine Safety Appliance Co. (MSA), which had specialized in safety products including firefighter’s helmets for decades.

Yellow with pale yellow synthetic strips and black velcros strips/ Colourless, transparent face shield with black mounting units/ Grey synthetic interior/ Yellow and black fabric strap, lining and padding/ Black strap with yellow clasp/ Plated metal clasps
Multicoloured label on front reads ‘FIRE – INCENDIE’ with fire department emblem and City of Ottawa logo

Comes with a liner and chin buckle./ The Velcro strip on each side of the helmet is used to attach an identification tag that serves as way of controlling who is involved in fighting the fire. On the tag was printed the kind of truck the fireman worked on (Pumper, ladder), and his employee number. This system is called Accountability and was initiated in the Ottawa Fire Department around the end of the 1990’s.

Commemorates a Canadian built fire engine. This coin, diffused around the world, depicts one fire engine made by Bickle Fire Engines Ltd. in 1932. R.S. Bickle established a fire fighting equipment manufacturing business in Winnipeg, MN in 1906 and in 1914 moved to Woodstock, ON. From 1928 to 1938 the company developed its own line of custom fire engines with four models, one of which was the Chieftain. The 1932 Chieftain Triple Combination Pumper was service in the Montreal West Fire Department from 1932 to 1969.
Used as a $1.00 coin in the Cook Islands of New Zealand and as a collectable item made to commemorate an antique fire engine.

One of a 5000 coin mintage. This coin acknowledges that in Canada, Canadian manufacturers of fire-fighting vehicles co-existed with American firms thanks to the specialty aspect of their production. This coin is the first of series entitled "Fire Engines of the World" produced by the Perth Mint in Australia

CONSISTS OF PIN WITH BACKING LOCK/ THE THIBAULT CO. ORIGINATED IN 1908 AT SOREL, QC UNDER CHARLES THIBAULT. HIS SON PIERRE TOOK OVER & OPENED A SMALL FACTORY IN ST. ROBERT, QC IN 1933 WHICH LATER MOVED TO PIERREVILLE, QC. IN 1957 THE COMPANY WAS INCORPORATED AS PIERRE THIBAULT CANADA LIMITEE WITH PIERRE AT THE HEAD. THESE PINS WERE USED AT FIRE CHIEFS' CONVENTIONS WHEN THE COMPANY STARTED DEVELOPING ITS NATIONAL MARKET IN THE EARLY 1960S. [REF.1]

30W non-detergent oil fogged into carburettor and exhaust port. Cylinder head removed, top of piston tapped with hardwood block & hammer to free piston. Corrosion & smeared aluminium from piston on cylinder wall removed with scalpel & fine Scotchbrite pad. Cylinder oiled again & engine turned over several times. Head reinstalled. Loose dust & dirt brushed & vacuumed off pump, motor & backpack.

Deterioration Notes: Motor would not turn initially, but about a week after oiling, a tap with a hardwood block and a hammer on top of the piston succeeded in freeing it. The top of the piston is pitted and corroded. The plastic on the rear of the switch dangling by two wires is broken. There is some corrosion and pitting of the aluminium on the pump interior. The foam on the inside of the backpack is intact. Accretion of dirt & oil.

Uniform identification badges used by Canadian forestry and forest fire fighting personnel, specifically of Prince Edward Island. The Provincial Forest Section is responsible for the sustainable management of the provinces publicly owned forest, including forest fire management. Fire suppression is carried out using Forest Section staff & equipment in conjunction with volunteer fire departments. Equipment includes six forest fire tanker/pumpers & two all terrain tracked tankers (Ref. 2).
Identifying patches worn on the uniforms of provincial forestry personnel, affixed to a shirt or jacket,.

An example of a machine embroidered fabric badge. For centuries embroidery hand been done by hand, but during the industrial revolution mechanization of the process began. Embroidery machines were designed by 1860, combining in a single machine handloom technology with the existing sewing machine technology, the lock-stitch. The automation was refined in the in the 1970s - early 1980s with automatic, electronically controlled custom embroidered machines developed in Japan. Instead of the instructions being coded on a continuous reel of paper or Mylar(r) tape containing x-y coordinate information in Binary, Fortran or other numeric code to control pantograph movement, the information is now digitized on computer disks. These machines also do the work flat instead of vertically which allows automatic colour changes (Ref. 1).
Contact: Mr. George Coade, Central District Provincial Forest Supervisor/ Received by CMSTC in 2003 (S. Beauvais, 23/11/2005)
1) Parsons, K. "History of Digitizing" in "Stitches Magazine", May 1, 2003 (in Supp. Info.2003.0253)
2) Government of P.E.I. Environment, Energy &Forestry website [http://www.gov.pe.ca/enveng/ffaw-info/index.php3 ] (in Supp. Info.)

Uniform identification badges used by Canadian forestry and forest fire fighting personnel, specifically of Newfoundland & Labrador. A dedicated forest fire fighting organization has existed in that province since 1905. In the modern forest fire fighting service, ground fire fighting crews operate out of 24 depots throughout Newfoundland & Labrador. The program also makes use of six water bombers, a spotter aircraft, & four helicopters from which two person Helitack (helicopter attack) crews can be deployed (Ref. 2) .
Identifying patches worn on the uniforms of provincial forestry personnel, affixed to a shirt or jacket.

An example of a machine embroidered fabric badge. For centuries embroidery hand been done by hand, but during the industrial revolution mechanization of the process began. The automation was refined in the in the 1970s - early 1980s with automatic, electronically controlled custom embroidered machines developed in Japan. Instead of the instructions being coded on a continuous reel of paper or Mylar(r) tape containing x-y coordinate information in Binary, Fortran or other numeric code to control pantograph movement, the information is now digitized on computer disks. Uniform identification badges used by Canadian forestry and forest fire fighting personnel, specifically of Alberta. This is the insignia of aerial firefighters. Aerial attack is defined as a fire suppression operation involving the use of deliver fire fighting forces, suppressants, or retardants to or on to a fire (Ref. 3).
Identifying patches worn on the uniforms of provincial fire fighting personnel, affixed to a shirt or jacket.

An example of a machine embroidered fabric badge. For centuries embroidery hand been done by hand, but during the industrial revolution mechanization of the process began. The automation was refined in the in the 1970s - early 1980s with automatic, electronically controlled custom embroidered machines developed in Japan. Instead of the instructions being coded on a continuous reel of paper or Mylar(r) tape containing x-y coordinate information in Binary, Fortran or other numeric code to control pantograph movement, the information is now digitized on computer disks. Alberta Sustainable Resource Development Forest Protection Rapattack

Uniform identification badges used by Canadian forestry and forest fire fighting personnel, specifically of Alberta. A Rapattack unit is an initial wildfire attack unit trained to descend from a specially equipped, hovering helicopter on a rope fitted with a mechanical device to control the rate of descent, a specialized form of helitack (helicopter firefighting unit). The Rapattack program is one of only two such programs in Canada, & has been in existence since 1983. The 7-person units undergo a month of intensive rappel training, including a physically demanding training course, emergency retrieval procedures & ongoing evaluations. The units are Edmonton based & to allow for quick response are transported to fires by 8 contracted medium rotary-wing aircraft (Ref. 3).
Identifying patches worn on the uniforms of provincial fire fighting personnel, affixed to a shirt or jacket.

An example of a machine embroidered fabric badge. For centuries embroidery hand been done by hand, but during the industrial revolution mechanization of the process began. Embroidery machines were designed by 1860, combining in a single machine handloom technology with the existing sewing machine technology, the lock-stitch. The automation was refined in the in the 1970s - early 1980s with automatic, electronically controlled custom embroidered machines developed in Japan. Instead of the instructions being coded on a continuous reel of paper or Mylar(r) tape containing x-y coordinate information in Binary, Fortran or other numeric code to control pantograph movement, the information is now digitized on computer disks. These machines also do the work flat instead of vertically which allows automatic colour changes (Ref. 1).

Alberta Sustainable Resource Development Forest Protection Helitack

Uniform identification badges used by Canadian forestry and forest fire fighting personnel, specifically of Alberta. This is the insignia of Helitack firefighters. Helitack is defined as the initial attack on wildfires involving the use of helicopters & trained crews, deployed as a complete unit. The crews are specially trained in the tactical & logistical use of helicopters for fire suppression (Ref. 3).
Identifying patches worn on the uniforms of provincial fire fighting personnel, affixed to a shirt or jacket.

Alberta Sustainable Resource Development Forest Protection Helitack

Uniform identification badges used by Canadian forestry and forest fire fighting personnel, specifically of Alberta. This is the insignia of Helitack firefighters. Helitack is defined as the initial attack on wildfires involving the use of helicopters & trained crews, deployed as a complete unit. The crews are specially trained in the tactical & logistical use of helicopters for fire suppression (Ref. 3).
Identifying patches worn on the uniforms of provincial fire fighting personnel, affixed to a shirt or jacket.

An example of a machine embroidered fabric badge. For centuries embroidery hand been done by hand, but during the industrial revolution mechanization of the process began. Embroidery machines were designed by 1860, combining in a single machine handloom technology with the existing sewing machine technology, the lock-stitch. The automation was refined in the in the 1970s - early 1980s with automatic, electronically controlled custom embroidered machines developed in Japan. Instead of the instructions being coded on a continuous reel of paper or Mylar(r) tape containing x-y coordinate information in Binary, Fortran or other numeric code to control pantograph movement, the information is now digitized on computer disks. These machines also do the work flat instead of vertically which allows automatic colour changes (Ref. 1).

Uniform identification badges used by Canadian forest fire fighting personnel, specifically of Ontario. In that province, fire detection & suppression is the responsibility of the Aviation & Forest Fire Management branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources, which provides aviation & forest fire management services. Ontario has had organized forest fire protection since 1885 & its air service marked its 75th anniversary in 1999, making it the longest, continuous flying government air service in the world, outside the military. (Ref. 2).

Uniform identification badges used by Canadian forestry and forest fire fighting personnel, specifically of British Columbia. In that province, three person initial attack crews respond first to fire calls & are of four types: Helitack crews exit from a hovering helicopter, Rapattack crews rappel from a helicopter, Parattack crews parachute from a fixed wing aircraft & Firetack ground crews are transported by truck. 20 person unit crews are dispatched to larger fires requiring significant resources to fight them (Ref. 2). This is the insignia of the mainstream Forestry Service (Ref. 3).
Identifying patches worn on the uniforms of provincial forestry personnel, affixed to a shirt or jacket.

The automation was refined in the in the 1970s - early 1980s with automatic, electronically controlled custom embroidered machines developed in Japan. Instead of the instructions being coded on a continuous reel of paper or Mylar(r) tape containing x-y coordinate information in Binary, Fortran or other numeric code to control pantograph movement, the information is now digitized on computer disks. These machines also do the work flat instead of vertically which allows automatic colour changes (Ref. 1).

Uniform identification badges used by Canadian forestry and forest fire fighting personnel, specifically of Alberta. Bertie Beaver was the mascot & "spokesbeaver" for the Alberta Forest Service, appearing on signs & litter bags, & in colouring book for children with a theme of fire prevention. 1998 was Bertie's 40th anniversary. Bertie Beaver was created in the U.S. on Walt Disney's cartoon drawing boards (possibly by Disney himself) & was given to Alberta as thanks for help Disney received from the Forestry Service during the making of a film in Alberta during the1950's. (See Supp. Info. for Bertie Beaver sign 1998.0593.)

Uniform identification badges used by Canadian forestry and forest fire fighting personnel, specifically of Alberta. This is the insignia of aerial firefighters. Aerial attack is defined as a fire suppression operation involving the use of deliver fire fighting forces, suppressants, or retardants to or on to a fire (Ref. 3).
Identifying patches worn on the uniforms of provincial fire fighting personnel, affixed to a shirt or jacket.

An example of a machine embroidered fabric badge. For centuries embroidery hand been done by hand, but during the industrial revolution mechanization of the process began. Embroidery machines were designed by 1860, combining in a single machine handloom technology with the existing sewing machine technology, the lock-stitch. The automation was refined in the in the 1970s - early 1980s with automatic, electronically controlled custom embroidered machines developed in Japan. Instead of the instructions being coded on a continuous reel of paper or Mylar(r) tape containing x-y coordinate information in Binary, Fortran or other numeric code to control pantograph movement, the information is now digitized on computer disks. These machines also do the work flat instead of vertically which allows automatic colour changes (Ref. 1).

Uniform identification badges used by Canadian forestry and forest fire fighting personnel, specifically of Alberta. Bertie Beaver was the mascot & "spokesbeaver" for the Alberta Forest Service, appearing on signs & litter bags, & in colouring book for children with a theme of fire prevention. 1998 was Bertie's 40th anniversary. Bertie Beaver was created in the U.S. on Walt Disney's cartoon drawing boards (possibly by Disney himself) & was given to Alberta as thanks for help Disney received from the Forestry Service during the making of a film in Alberta during the1950's. (See Supp. Info. for Bertie Beaver sign 1998.0593.)
Identifying patches worn on the uniforms of provincial forestry personnel, affixed to a shirt or jacket.

An example of a machine embroidered fabric badge. For centuries embroidery hand been done by hand, but during the industrial revolution mechanization of the process began. Embroidery machines were designed by 1860, combining in a single machine handloom technology with the existing sewing machine technology, the lock-stitch. The automation was refined in the in the 1970s - early 1980s with automatic, electronically controlled custom embroidered machines developed in Japan. Instead of the instructions being coded on a continuous reel of paper or Mylar(r) tape containing x-y coordinate information in Binary, Fortran or other numeric code to control pantograph movement, the information is now digitized on computer disks. These machines also do the work flat instead of vertically which allows automatic colour changes (Ref. 1).

BERTIE BEAVER IS MASCOT & "SPOKESBEAVER" FOR ALBERTA FOREST SERVICE, APPEARING ON SIGNS & LITTER BAGS, & IN COLOURING BOOK FOR CHILDREN WITH THEME OF FIRE PREVENTION. 1998 WAS BERTIE'S 40TH ANNIVERSARY (SEE SUPP. INFO.)
SIGN WITH MOVABLE INDICATOR TO INDICATE DEGREE OF FOREST FIRE HAZARD BETWEEN LOW & EXTREME.

BERTIE BEAVER WAS CREATED IN U.S. ON WALT DISNEY'S CARTOON DRAWING BOARDS (POSSIBLY BY DISNEY HIMSELF) & WAS GIVEN TO ALBERTA AS THANKS FOR HELP DISNEY RECEIVED FROM FORESTRY SERVICE DURING MAKING OF FILM IN ALBERTA DURING 1950'S.
SIGN PAINTED WHITE/ BEAVER FIGURE PAINTED BROWN, WHITE, BACK & GOLD/ RED, ORANGE, YELLOW & GREEN DOTS TO INDICATE FIRE HAZARD
FIRE HAZARD SIGN FEATURING ALBERTA LAND & FOREST SERVICE MASCOT "BERTIE BEAVER"

TO PROTECT THE HEAD OF A FIREFIGHTER WHILE FIRE FIGHTING.

EARLIEST RECOGNIZABLE FIRE HELMETS WERE MADE OF LEATHER; IN 1920S ALUMINUM, AND THEN COMPOSITE MATERIALS (FIBREGLASS, +) WERE USED. THESE HELMETS WERE LIGHTER, MORE RESILIENT, AND OFFERED FIREFIGHTERS A GREATER DEGREE OF PROTECTION AND COMFORT THAN EARLY HELMETS. BLACK COLOUR HELMET IS WORNBY ORDINARY FIREFIGHTERS.

Protective coverall is one element of standard outfit worn by New Brunswick Natural Resources and Energy regular Fire Service personnel in 2002.
Flame resistant clothing protects wearer, and identifies him/her as a member of the New Brunswick Fire Service.

One-piece coverall made of Nomex III flame resistant fabric. In addition to protecting wearer from injuries caused by burning or melting clothing, this coverall reduces exposure to brush, insects and sunlight, and improves wearer's visibility, clearly identifying him/her as a member of the Fire Service.
This type of coverall worn 2002; possibly also earlier/later. This example worn prior to donation.

Bright yellow woven fabric coveralls have metal zipper closure on front; black velcro closures on neck, wrists and ankles. Length of silver reflective fabric sewn to back, across shoulders, and on lower front of pant legs. Black, green and yellow shoulder flashes and red & white embroidered Canadian flag badge sewn to coveralls. Black text and graphic appears on coverall back.

NB Natural Resources and Energy machine stitched fabric badges sewn to shoulders incorporate small yellow sailing ship motif; small red & white Canadian flag sewn to proper upper left front. Single coniferous tree and text printed in black on coverall back.

Complete NB Forest Service fire suppression outfit includes coverall (2005.0024.001); hard hat (2005.0024.002); safety goggles (2005.0024.003); work gloves (2005.0024.004-.005); radio, in carrying harness (2005.0024.006-.007); and belt, with fanny pack carrying case, a hose strangler holder, and a short length of hose fitted with a quick-connect coupling (2005.0024.008).

CANADIAN MADE FIRE VEHICLE OF TYPE POPULAR WITH SMALL TOWN FIRE DEPARTMENTS IN CANADA. SON OF SOREL WAGON MFR., PIERRE THIBAULT DESIGNED PUMP & BEGAN HISBUSINESS IN ST. ROBERT IN 1932 & THEN IN PIERREVILLE IN 1938; BY 1956 IT WAS MAJOR MFR. OF FIRE FIGHTING VEHICLES IN CANADA. FOUR WHEEL DRIVE CO. BEGAN IN 1907.
MOTORIZED VEHICLE USED TO TO TRANSPORT FIRE FIGHTING PERSONNEL, EQUIPMENT, & WATER TO SCENE OF FIRE; & TO PUMP & DIRECT WATER ONTO FLAMES IN ORDER TO SUPPRESS/EXTINGUISH FIRE.

EARLY MOTORIZED FIRE ENGINE USED BY CANADIAN FIRE DEPT. IT WAS IMPORTED FROM U.S. IN 1914 AS PART OF AMERICAN LAFRANCE DISPLAY AT FIRE CHIEF'S CONVENTION IN LONDON, ON, & PURCHASED THERE BY STRATFORD FIRE DEPT. IT WAS ONE OF FIRST MOTORIZED FIRE SERVICES VEHICLES IN STRATFORD & HAS 6 CYLINDER ENGINE, NOT USUAL 4 CYLINDER.

MOTORIZED VEHICLE USED TO TO TRANSPORT FIRE FIGHTING PERSONNEL, FIRE HOSES, & CHEMICAL EXTINGUISHER TO SCENE OF FIRE. IT CARRIED HOSES TO BE USED BY PUMPERS & HAD 2 TANKS OF CARBON DIOXIDE EXTINGUISHER PRODUCED BY COMBINING SULPHURIC ACID & BICARBONATE OF SODA.

COMBINATION HOSE & CHEMICAL FIRE TRUCK CARRIED HOSES FOR CONVENTIONAL PUMPERS AS WELL AS TANKS OF CARBON DIOXIDE. IN PERIOD WHEN LOCAL WATER SUPPLY WAS NOT ALWAYS AVAILABLE & STEAM PUMPERS TOOK TIME TO READY, CHEMICAL ENGINES WERE READY FOR USE UPON ARRIVAL. FIRST INTRODUCED IN 1872, THEY CONTINUED IN USE UNTIL 1930'S. CHEMICAL SYSTEMS WERE INITIALLY AVAILABLE IN HAND-DRAWN & HORSE-DRAWN VERSIONS.
THIS EXAMPLE USED 1914 TO LATE 1920'S; THEN USED AS BACKUP & LATER FOR CEREMONIAL PURPOSES
STRATFORD, ON - USED BY STRATFORD FIRE DEPT.

Long-term storage procedures. Draining of fluids, fogging of engine interior, etc.

Radiator cap removed. Drain cock on lower rad hose was removed and small amount of fluid was drained. Lower rad hose was removed and the cooling system air dried (shop-vac) for 1 hour. Rad cap was placed in a bag and reemay was placed over opening. Spark plugs were removed from engine. Drain plugs were removed from bottom of crankcase (no real oil pan.) Oil was drained. Plugs were reinstalled. Engine was fogged only through the spark plug openings. Spark plugs were reinstalled.
Yes - Vehicle may contain radiator antifreeze (ethylene glycol.)

Long-term storage procedures. Draining of fluids, fogging of engine interior, etc.

Radiator cap removed. Drain cock on lower rad hose and on pr. right side of water jacket were opened and coolant allowed to drain. Cooling system was air dried (shop-vac) for 1 hour. Drain cocks were closed. Spark plugs, oil fill cap and dipstick were removed. Oil pan plug was removed and oil drained. Plug was reinstalled, 2-3 litres of 30 non-detergent oil was added to engine. Engine was fogged while being turned over. Spark plugs, etc. were reinstalled.

Type of smoke detectors used in Canadian homes.
To detect airborne smoke and alert about its presence.

20th century invention. Was mass-produced beginning in the 1970's. This type of detector detects small particles of smoke too small to be visible. It includes a tiny mass of radiation. The radiation passes through an ionization chamber, which is an air-filled space between two electrodes and permits a small, constant current to flow between the electrodes. Any smoke that enters the chamber absorbs the alpha particles, which reduces the ionization and interrupts this flow of current, setting off the alarm. Hot air entering the chamber changes the rate of ionization and therefore, the electric current level which triggers an alarm" from www.mvfra.org. It is less expensive than an optical detector. It is equipped with a test button to see if it works well.

TYPE OF FIRE ENGINE BOUGHT BY CANADIAN CITIES WHICH HAD ADEQUATE WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS. PARTICULALY POPULAR STARTING IN THE 1860S. FOR EXAMPLE, SAINT JOHN (NB) PURCHASED 2 AMOSKEAG ENGINES IN 1863 & 1 IN 1864; WINDSOR (ON) BOUGHT 1 IN 1868.

STEAMERS WERE FIRST INVENTED IN 1852 BY ALEXANDER &MOSES LATTA & ABEL SHANK. AMOSKEAG STEAM PUMP WAS CONCEIVED NY NEHEMIAH S. BEAN, LOCOMOTIVE WORKMAN AT MANCHESTER LOCOMOTIVE WORKS. GRADUALLY STEAM PUMPS REPLACED HAND PUMPS IN CITIES; STARTING CA. 1910, STEAMERS WERE GRADUALLY REPLACED BY MOTORIZED FIRE ENGINES. INTRODUCTION OF STEAMERS MAY HAVE PLAYED ROLE IN DEVELOPMENT OF PROFESSIONAL FIRE DEPTS. (SEE S.I.)
U.S. NAVY SHIP YARD AT CHARLESTON, MASS. WAS ORIGINAL OWNER.

This is one of 3 trucks of this model purchased by Montreal in 1927. Seagrave operated subsidiary plants in Walkerville, Ont. (W.E. seagrave fire apparatus, 1900-1919), and in St.Catharines, Ont. (Seagrave Fire Engine Ltd., 1930- 1935).
Used to transport personnel & equipment to site of fire, and to pump and direct water onto fire in order to suppress/extinguish it.

New standard model introduced in 1929. Pump pressure equalled 1000 gallons per minute. Although of the standard model, Montreal trucks like this example were equipped with special extra-large hose bodies, which could hold 2000 feet of hose (Ref. 3)
Used specifically at station no. 25, Drummond St., Montreal, Que.
Transfers: Gold striping & scroll work with black borders.

Engine specs: 6 Cyl.; 5 3/4 in. bore X 6 1/2 in. stroke; 1015 cu.in. displacement; 130 B.H.P.; Triple ignition fuel consumption; 5 M. per gal./ Quebec registration on file/ Key: 2-042/ Restoration: Restored to original condition by E.A. Sprenger & his son Alec, 1961-1969/ See S.I. file for inventory of items affixed to or on fire truck/ N.B. Damage report on file (1985.07.04)

Roy Belshaw was a life-long Waterous employee. In 1993, he rescued (with permission) an extraordinary collection of Waterous company material from the dumpster into which it had been thrown. Over and above the historical significance of the Waterous firm, it is the completeness of the records saved by Mr. Belshaw that make this collection unique. For once, a detailed internal study of a Canadian firm like this can be carried out against its record of production. The collection also includes a great deal of material that documents the social and plant life of the workers.
Used to control the flow of water from a fire hose.

The Waterous firm (under various names) was one of Canada's pioneering equipment manufacturers. Located in Brantford, it was one of Canada's longest lasting heavy equipment manufacturers - producing agricultural, steam, fire, and especially logging equipment from 1844-1992.
Brass tip ,followed by rubber sleeve over metal, followed by red painted body. Threaded interior connector. Red paint has mostly flaked off.

LIQUID PYRENE REFILL FOR PYRENE FIRE EXTINGUISHERS, MADE IN TORONTO ONTARIO BY CANADIAN BRANCH OF PYRENE MFG. CO.
USED TO REFILL DEPLEATED PYRENE FIRE EXTINGUISHERS.

PYRENE FIRE EXTINGUISERS POPULAR IN FIRST HALF OF 20TH CENTURY. PYRENE WAS EFFECTIVE IN FIGHTING GREASE, GASOLINE, ELECTRICAL AND REFUSE FIRES. IT IS EXTREMELY TOXIC, FORMING A POISONOUS GAS WHEN SUBJECTED TO EXTREME HEAT: IT IS ALSO POISONOUS IF INGESTED.
THIS TYPE OF PRODUCT PRESUBABLY USED C. 1910-1930S, AND POSSIBLY LATER. THIS CAN NEVER USED.
THIS TYPE OF PRODUCT USED IN CANADA, USA & EUROPE; POSSIBLY ALSO ELSEWHERE. THIS CAN UNOPENED.

HIGHLY DETAILED DECALS DEPICT FIRE EXTINGUISHERS: TEXT IN ENGLISH & FRENCH ON EXTINGUISHERS IS LEGIBLE.

TYPE OF PUMPER MADE & USED IN CANADA, PARTICULARLY IN VILLAGES OF PRAIRIES, WHERE NO HYDRANTS EXISTED. THEY WERE ECONOMICAL REPLACEMENT FOR STEAM PUMPERS.
USED TO PROVIDE WATER TO SUPPRESS FIRES

FIRST GASOLINE DRIVEN FIRE PUMPS ON MARKET. THEY WERE MADE IN BRANTFORD & ST. PAUL WATEROUS FACTORIES FROM 1898 TO 1910. ONE CYLINDER MODEL WAS CREATED FIRST & WAS RATED AT 175 GPM (GALLONS PER MINUTE). DESIGN TOOK 2 YEARS OF EXPERIMENTAL WORK (1895-1897). IN C. 1913 700 WATEROUS GASOLINE FIRE ENGINES WERE IN SERVICE IN CANADA & USA.
